{{Other people}} {{blprefimprove|date=October 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Michael McIntyre | image = Michael McIntyre - Soho Theatre - Monday 15th May 2017 McIntyreSoho150517-10 (34683587845) (cropped).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = McIntyre at the [[Soho Theatre]] in 2017 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Michael Hazen James McIntyre | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|02|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[London Borough of Merton|Merton]], London, England | death_date = | death_place = | medium = [[Stand up comedy|Stand-up]], television | active = 1999–present | genre = [[Satire|Social satire]], [[Observational comedy]] | subject = | influences = [[Woody Allen]], [[Billy Connolly]]{{cite web |url= http://www.chortle.co.uk/books/2010/10/16/11946/life_and_laughter_by_michael_mcintyre |title=Life and Laughter Autobiography |work=Chortle |date=16 October 2010}} | influenced = | spouse = {{marriage|Kitty McIntyre|2003}} | domesticpartner = | children = 2 | parents = [[Ray Cameron (comedian)|Ray Cameron]]
Kati Cameron | notable_work = ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'' (2007–09)
''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow|Comedy Roadshow]]'' (2009—11)
''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' (2011)
''[[Comic Relief]]'' (2011—)
''[[The Michael McIntyre Chat Show]]'' (2014)
''[[Michael McIntyre's Big Show]]'' (2016—) | signature = | website = [http://www.michaelmcintyre.co.uk Official website] | footnotes = | module = {{Listen| embed=yes |filename = Michael_mcintyre_bbc_radio4_desert_island_discs_17_07_2011.flac |title = Michael McIntyre's voice |type = speech |description = from the BBC programme ''[[Desert Island Discs]]'', 17 July 2011.{{Cite episode | title= Michael McIntyre |series= [[Desert Island Discs]] |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b012jf8n |station= [[BBC Radio 4]] |date= 17 July 2011 |accessdate= 18 January 2014 }} }} }} '''Michael Hazen James McIntyre''' (born 21 February 1976) is an English comedian, actor, and TV presenter. In 2012, he was reported to be the highest-grossing comedian in the world.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/comedy/9792765/McIntyre-is-worlds-most-successful-comedian.html|location=London|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=McIntyre is world's most successful comedian|date=25 January 2013}} In addition to stand-up, McIntyre has hosted his own [[BBC One]] comedy programme ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'', has featured in three episodes of ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'' and, in 2011, was a judge on ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]''. He currently presents his own Saturday night series ''[[Michael McIntyre's Big Show]]'' on [[BBC One]]. ==Personal life== McIntyre resides in [[Hampstead, London]] with his [[Aromatherapy|aromatherapist]] wife, Kitty, who is a daughter of the late actor [[Simon Ward]] and sister of actress [[Sophie Ward]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-18947130|title=The Tudors actor Simon Ward dies after long illness|work=BBC News}} The couple have two sons, Lucas and Oscar.{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Bryony|title=Michael McIntyre interview: 'Maybe people just can’t cope with how jovial I am'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/comedy/9663797/Michael-McIntyre-interview-Maybe-people-just-cant-cope-with-how-jovial-I-am.html|accessdate=27 June 2016|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|agency=telegraph.co.uk|date=11 November 2012}} McIntyre is a supporter of [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/sol/newsid_7260000/newsid_7260300/7260343.stm|title=Comedian issues Spurs rallying call|publisher=BBC|accessdate=20 July 2009|date=23 February 2008}} McIntyre is also a keen [[cricket]] fan and has appeared on [[Test Match Special]] to discuss the sport.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01czjtt|title=BBC Radio 5 live sports extra - Test Match Special, 18/07/2013, The Ashes: Michael McIntyre joins TMS|work=BBC}} On 4 June 2018, McIntyre was robbed of a [[Rolex]] watch while parked outside his children's school.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-44364912 |title=Michael McIntyre robbed by men on moped |date=5 June 2018 |work=[[BBC]] |access-date=5 June 2018}}{{Cite news |url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/06/05/michael-mcintyre-forced-hand-knife-wielding-robber-15000-watch-shocking-daylight-robbery-7608652/ |title=Michael McIntyre forced to hand knife-wielding robber £15,000 watch in shocking daylight robbery |last=Evans |first=Mel |date=5 June 2018 |work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |access-date=5 June 2018}} ==Career== ===Television=== [[File:Michael McIntyre.jpg|thumb|left|175px|McIntyre at the [[British Academy Television Awards 2009]].]] Aged 13, Michael was in the audience of the BBC One Saturday morning show [[Going Live!]] on 1 April 1989, where he appeared on camera asking a question to pop group [[Five Star]]. McIntyre has appeared three times on BBC One's ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'', in 2007, 2008 and 2009. He has released four DVDs, ''Live and Laughing'', ''Hello Wembley'', ''Showtime'' and ''Happy and Glorious'', that have sold a combined total of over five million copies in the UK.{{cite web|last=Cox |first=Gordon |url=https://variety.com/2012/legit/news/mcintyre-luring-fans-for-live-and-laughing-1118062107/ |title=McIntyre: Luring fans for 'Live and Laughing' |publisher=Variety |date=15 November 2012 |accessdate=30 July 2013}} McIntyre's many comedy panel show and chat show appearances include ''[[Chris Moyles' Quiz Night]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[8 out of 10 Cats]]'', ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[The Big Fat Quiz of the Year]]'', ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie To You?]]'', ''[[The Apprentice: You're Fired!]]'', ''[[Alan Carr: Chatty Man]]'' and ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]''. From 6 June 2009, McIntyre began hosting ''[[Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow]]'', which aired Saturday nights on BBC One. On 5 July 2009, McIntyre appeared on the BBC show ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]'' as the "star in a reasonably priced car", driving around the [[Top Gear test track]] in one minute and 48.7 seconds. During his lap of the track he almost rolled the car while going around the final corner; but his hair was kempt. On 31 March 2010, McIntyre took part in ''[[Channel 4's Comedy Gala]]'', a benefit show held in aid of [[Great Ormond Street Hospital]], filmed live at London's O2 Arena. He also appeared on the year's edition of ''[[The Big Fat Quiz of the Year]]'' on [[Channel 4]], where he was partnered with [[Alan Carr]]. On 14 December 2010, it was announced that McIntyre would join the ITV talent show ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' as a judge in 2011 with [[David Hasselhoff]] and [[Amanda Holden]]. McIntyre and Hasselhoff replaced [[Piers Morgan]] and [[Simon Cowell]], although Cowell returned for the live shows. Following the series, McIntyre announced that he would be leaving the show after appearing for one series.{{cite web|url=http://talent.itv.com/2010/news/article/read_new-bgt-judges-revealed_item_100783.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713070346/http://talent.itv.com/2010/news/article/read_new-bgt-judges-revealed_item_100783.html|title=New BGT judges revealed!|archivedate=13 July 2011|work=itv.com}} In 2010 and 2014, McIntyre hosted the [[Royal Variety Performance]] on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/press-releases/michael-mcintyre-host-royal-variety-performance-2014|title=Michael McIntyre to host The Royal Variety Performance 2014|work=presscentre}} He also previously performed on the show twice: in 2006 and 2008. McIntyre co-hosted various segments of ''[[Comic Relief]]'' in 2011 and 2013 on [[BBC One]]. On Christmas Day 2011, McIntyre hosted a Christmas Special edition of ''Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow''. The show was watched by 8.1 million viewers.{{cite web|url= http://www.televisual.com/news-detail/Downton-Abbey-overtakes-EastEnders-in-updated-Xmas-ratings_nid-1019.html|title= Downton Abbey overtakes EastEnders in updated Xmas ratings|work=televisual.com|date= |accessdate=4 January 2012}} In 2014 McIntyre fronted his own [[BBC One]] talk programme, ''[[The Michael McIntyre Chat Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a544078/michael-mcintyre-lands-his-own-bbc-one-chatshow.html|title=Michael McIntyre lands his own BBC One chatshow|work=Digital Spy}} A Christmas special aired on Christmas Day in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/michael_mcintyre_xmas_show/|title=Michael McIntyre's Very Christmassy Christmas Show - BBC1 Variety|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide|comedy.co.uk]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}} On 5 April 2015, Michael presented ''Michael McIntyre Presents...Easter Night at the Coliseum'', a one-off special for [[BBC One]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05ql1nj|title=Michael McIntyre's Easter Night at the Coliseum - BBC One|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/michael_mcintyre_presents/|title=Michael McIntyre's Easter Night At The Coliseum - BBC1 Variety|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide|comedy.co.uk]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}} In November 2015, it was announced that McIntyre would return to [[BBC One]] for ''Michael McIntyre's Big Christmas Show''. The show was recorded in front of a live audience in the Theatre Royal in London before airing on Christmas Day.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2015/michael-mcintyre-christmas|title=BBC - Michael McIntyre’s Big Christmas Show returns to BBC One this Christmas - Media Centre|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001952/michael_mcintyre_big_christmas_show_2015/|title=Michael McIntyre to host another BBC Christmas special|date=10 November 2015|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide|comedy.co.uk]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}} Since April 2016, McIntyre has presented ''[[Michael McIntyre's Big Show]]'', a Saturday night entertainment series for [[BBC One]]. A second series began airing in November 2016. A third series began airing in November 2017.http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2016/michael-mcintyres-big-show-bbc-one ===Stage=== McIntyre has performed three times on the ''[[Royal Variety Performance]]'', including in 2010 when he became the youngest ever host.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8605737.stm|title=Michael McIntyre to host Royal Variety Performance|work=BBC|date=|accessdate=25 January 2013}} In 2009, McIntyre performed for an estimated total of 500,000 people on his first tour of the United Kingdom that included a record-breaking six nights at [[Wembley Arena]] and four at [[The O2 Arena]]. In 2012, his UK tour included 71 arena dates, playing to over 700,000 people, including a record breaking 10 nights at the [[O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in London. According to ticket sales company Pollstar the tour helped make McIntyre the world's biggest selling comedian in 2012, bringing in around £21m.{{cite web|url= http://www.suchsmallportions.com/news/michael-mcintyre-worlds-best-selling-comedian-2012|title= Michael McIntyre world's best-selling comedian in 2012|work=www. suchsmallportions.com|date= |accessdate=8 January 2013}} On 20 April 2013 McIntyre played the biggest comedy gig in Africa to 9,000 fans at the Coca-Cola Dome in Johannesburg.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} In 2015, McIntyre toured the UK and Ireland with his "Happy & Glorious" tour. In February 2016, he took the tour to [[Norway]] for two dates, and in October 2016 he took it to Australia for four dates. Between early 2017 and mid-2019, McIntyre will be performing 104 shows in 5 continents during his world tour, ''[[Michael McIntyre's Big World Tour]]''.www.michaelmcintyre.co.uk/big-world-tour/ ===Radio=== McIntyre's radio appearances have included: *''[[Does the Team Think?]]'' ([[BBC Radio 2]]) *''Heresy'', ''[[4 Stands Up]]'', ''Happy Mondays'', ''[[The Unbelievable Truth (radio show)|The Unbelievable Truth]]'' (all on [[BBC Radio 4]]) *''[[The Jon Richardson Show]]'' ([[BBC 6 Music]]) *''The Jonathan Ross Show'' ([[BBC Radio 2]]) *''[[The Chris Moyles Show]]'' ([[BBC Radio 1]]) *''[[Desert Island Discs]]'' ([[BBC Radio 4]]){{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b012jf8n |title=Desert Island Discs – Michael McIntyre |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=22 July 2011 |accessdate=30 July 2013}} ===Books=== In 2010, McIntyre released his autobiography, "Life and Laughing: My Story".{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/dec/13/celebrity-memoirs-bestsellers-autobiography-christmas |title=Why celebrity memoirs rule publishing |last1=Harris |first1=Jogn |last2= |first2= |date=13 December 2010 |website=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |accessdate=17 January 2014}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Easter Night at the Coliseum''{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2015/michael-mcintyre|title=BBC - Michael McIntyre returns to BBC One this Easter - Media Centre|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=27 June 2016}} | Presenter | One-off entertainment show |- | 2015– | ''[[Michael McIntyre's Big Show]]'' | Presenter | 3 series + 3 Christmas specials |- |} ===Guest appearances=== *''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]'' (2006, 2008) – Panellist *''[[Mock the Week]]'' (2007, 2008) – Panellist *''[[Have I Got News For You]]'' (2007, 2008) – Panellist *''[[Would I Lie to You?
